I have to admit, I was looking forward to seeing Hotel Transylvania 2 ever since I first heard that they were doing it.  And the film definitely does not disappoint.  Which is not surprising as they had the same creative team and talent behind this new movie as they did behind the original.  Directed by Genndy Tartakovsky (Hotel Transylvania, Star Wars: Clone Wars, Samurai Jack) from a screenplay by Adam Sandler and Robert Smigel (You Don't Mess with the Zohan, Saturday Night Live), Hotel Transylvania 2 is a seamless follow up to its predecessor with everything, including the animation, taken up a notch.

A couple of years have passed since we first saw the Hotel Transylvania when Dracula (Adam Sandler), who had built the hotel as a kind of secret sanctuary where monsters could periodically escape to to get away from the much dreaded humans, had to deal first with the crisis of the hotel's discovery by a genially goofy human backpacker named Jonathan (Andy Samberg), and then with the much bigger crisis of Jonathan meeting his teenage daughter Mavis (Selena Gomez) and the two of them immediately "zinging" (also known as love at first sight).  But things worked out and, as we see in the film's beginning, Jonathan and Mavis get married, nature (human and vampire) takes its course, and Dracula is now a doting grand-dad, to Jonathan and Mavis' adorable toddler Dennis (Asher Blinkoff).  With the delight of course being shared by Mavis' extended monster family:  Frankenstein (Kevin James) and his Franken-wife Eunice (Fran Drescher), buttoned-down wolfman Wayne (Steve Buscemi) and his were-spouse Wanda (Molly Shannon) and their feral pack of were-kids, the invisible man Griffin (David Spade) and the mummy-with-the-most Murray (this time voiced by Keegan-Michael Key).

But of course there has to be a crisis, and this time it comes in twin worries for the Count.  The first worry is that Dennis, who's supposed to be half-vampire after all, is showing no signs of becoming a vampire, much to Drac's chagrin and embarrassment. But the second worry hits even harder:  Mavis feels that the hotel, much as she loves it, is not a safe place for a human child to be raised and is talking about leaving so that she and Jonathan can raise Dennis in a safer environment. Unable to bear the thought of not having his beloved daughter and grandson around, Dracula and his buddies have to find a way to get Dennis's latent vampire-ness to emerge before Mavis makes the final decision for the family to move.

While there is a certain predictability to a lot of the situations that arise, Tartakovsky deals with it smartly by keeping things moving and focusing on how the characters deal with things, each in their own distinctly individual way, and the fun lies in watching how things play out. There's a lot of affection for these characters not only in the way they're written in the script but also in the way they're given life by the animators and by the voice actors playing them, and that is what really drives the film and makes it fun for everyone.

With the exception of Murray, originally voiced by CeeLo Green, pretty much all of the voice actors from the first movie are back in their familiar roles, doing a superb job of bringing the Hotel characters to life. One notable change though is that Jon Lovitz, who voiced the hotel's hunchback chef Quasimodo Wilson in the first film, is this time the voice of the Phantom of the Opera, now apparently employed as the hotel's lounge singer. Among the new characters and voices is Dana Carvey as Dana, the safety-first feelings-are-good vampire camp counselor, though the hands down stand-out is Mel Brooks, perfectly cast as Dracula's dad, the crotchety cantankerous Vlad.  And like I said earlier, the animation, which was already pretty good in the first film, appears to have been taken up a notch in this new one, with added levels of detail and texture that really give depth to the settings and the characters.  This is definitely the kind of movie you want to get the DVD for so that you can go back and catch all of the little throw-away details and references that have been worked into it.

Also returning is Mark Mothersbaugh (Hotel Transylvania, Pitch Perfect 2, The Lego Movie) to provide the musical score which nicely adds to the overall feeling of the animation and the character interactions playing out on the screen.

My one real quibble with the movie is that the story doesn't flow as smoothly as it did in the first film. The first two-thirds of Hotel Transylvania 2 seem a bit choppy by comparison, jumping rather than flowing  from scene to scene, which made it hard for the film to build up momentum. But that said, when things do get going they get going in a big way, and the payoff when it comes delivers in highly satisfying ways on every level, making it all worthwhile.

The DVD details don't indicate what, if any, the extras will be, but I'm hoping they'll include a featurette I saw with the film's production designer Michael Kurinsky where he gives some background on what went into the animation and the design, which is quite interesting and gives you an idea of the level of thought required to pull off the things you see in the movie.

Highly, highly recommended for anyone who loves animation, family comedy and classic movie-monster riffs.

As a Christian family, we do not celebrate Halloween and other holidays unrelated to God. This movie was on our 'no' list ...and I feel rather foolish for having it be on that list. I just watched it alone and did NOT stop laughing. We then watched it as a family and kids were loving it just as much as the adults. It is not the monster aspect that concerns my family, it's the values and purpose. This movie is about family, love, being different AND important... being friends with lots of people  (aka monsters and humans)... just all around good social skills. Jokes, while a bit adult like, were rather tactful. I am so proud of the cast who created this tale as it's just a genuine love for family, forgiveness and being yourself. Wish I could hug the crew who created this. Will likely buy on DVD!

Just got back from seeing it in theaters, and let me tell you, there were several moments when just the kids would laugh, and moments when just the adults would laugh, and even moments when everybody laughed.
This is coming from a guy who doesn't watch a lot of "kid" movies, and I can tell Adam Sandler wanted more than just kids to enjoy it, so he threw in child-raising jokes, nipple jokes, and a few other jokes and themes that go right over your average kid's head. And of course there's silliness plentiful for the kiddies to enjoy.
If you're reading reviews, you should already be familiar with the plot, which in a nutshell for those who aren't, is basically the two kids from the first one are older and married and have a kid, who the grandfather, Count Dracula, hopes is a Dracula/monster like his own bloodline, but it doesn't seem to be the case. So family relationships are slightly strained in this movie as Dracula wonders if he'll be helping to raise his vampire grandson, or watching his human grandson and human son-in-law and vampire daughter move away and leaving him behind alone in his hotel, to go live with *gasp* HUMANS.
So on top of it being hilarious for everybody, there's a lot more to it as well. Obviously if you're a fan of the first Hotel Transylvania, it's a guarantee you'll enjoy this sequel. The style of animation is exaggerated, highly sporadic, like a human gas molecule with ADHD and an IV inserted coffee bag. There is a lot going on in almost every scene, and with the characters behaving so hyper, it may take a couple viewings to take in all in. The humor is quick, very in your face, but welcoming. And trust me, humor is a-plenty.
There are a few minor flaws; while tailored to two separate audiences, obviously there will be moments where one side will feel out of place. Either a child will cock their head to the side in puzzlement and maybe laugh but only because the adults are, or an adult will think to themselves "well that was just weird." And yes it's mostly a kid's movie so much of everything is easy to swallow.
Go see it, even if you don't have kids, it's a fun, easy-going flick that's sure to make you jiggle with joy like Blobby. The characters are fun and diverse as before, humor is constant, and for those sticklers out there (you know who you are), the plot exists and it flows sufficiently enough to follow, and at a reasonable pace. So bust out your popcorn and brain juice, and enjoy this light-hearted comedy.

Hotel Transylvania 2

  (WARNING! Spoilers are contained in the following!)

Plot: A couple of years after the events of the first Hotel Transylvania, Mavis and Jonathan have married, and had a son named Dennis. But in Papa Dracs eyes, Mavis is still his little girl.
  As Dennis grows older, his family begins to wonder if hes even a monster! For one thing, he has an un-vampire crop of curly red hair. And he has yet to sprout his fangs.
  Dracula insists that he is late fanger, and he insists that hell soon be a true vampire.
But Mavis feels that the Hotel is too dangerous for a human to live there. She and Jonathan decide to move to California where he grew up.
  Dracula, however, does not Mavis to go away. He comes up with a plan with all his monster friends: Teach Dennis how to be a proper monster. When Mavis sees her vampire son, surely shell change her mind about moving!

  The Seven Questions.

1. Is it funny?
Like the first movie, Hotel Transylvania 2 is one of those Single-Purpose movies. In this case, the goal is to keep the audience laughing. This means youll find a wide range of gags in this movie. Slapstick, Wisecracks...Toilet humor, etc, etc, etc.
  Ill admit, some of the jokes were genuinely funny, such as Dracula struggling with the mysteries of technology. There are even references to Phantom of the Opera and Sesame Street!
  But because the movie puts so much effort into being funny, everything else (animation, acting, music and, most importantly, story) is lacking in quality.

2. Is it romantic?
Mavis and Jonathan are married, as you know. There are some lovey-dovey moments between them where they exchange overly-cliched lines such as: Youre perfect the way you are!
  All the rest of their dialogue consists of Mavis worrying about Dennis and Jonathan insisting: Hes fine! That is not romantic.

3. Is it thrilling?
Over the years, thanks to modern conveniences seeping into Transylvania, all the monsters have become so...domesticated.
  When Dracula insists that his buddies show Dennis how to be a monster (by killing a deer, conjuring up a sandstorm, and so on) they fail.
  To make it worse, when they do make an effort to scare humans, the humans  are either indifferent, or starstruck (starstruck? By Frankensteins monster?! Give me a break!!)
  Most of the film focuses on Draculas unexciting attempts to vampirize his grandson.
But in a final attempt to be exciting, the filmmakers threw in a completely random human-hating bat villain. The battle that ensues becomes predictable within thirty seconds. Why couldn't they cut out the villain and make the movie 20 minutes shorter?
  In short? No, this movie is not thrilling.

4. Is it heartwarming?
There are moments that couldve been heartwarming, such as the birth of Dennis. Unfortunately, even these moments don't hit the mark because of all the humor.

5. Is there anything else I liked?
Unlike the last film, Hotel Transylvania doesnt rely so heavily on the potty humor.

6. Is there any negative elements?
If I were pick a word that summed up everything wrong with Hotel Transylvania,  it would be: Juvenile.
All the characters in the movie act like a bunch of whiny, clinging, immature kids. Even Mavis, the most mature monster in the bunch, goes crazy over pinatas and slurpees.
  Then theres also the films theme, which appears to be: Accept one anothers differences.
Everyone in Denniss family (with the exception of Drac) believes hes all-human. At first, Drac seemed okay with it.
  But then Mavis says shes thinking about moving. And Drac is still not ready to let his daughter grow up (Let her go already!!) Once again, his desire to keep his baby-girl home leads him to make some pretty poor choices. Including trying to make Dennis something hes not.
  Finally a furious Mavis orders her dad to lay off! Let him be a human! Then she starts packing.
Now Drac finally realizes that he shouldve listened to his friends.
  Then...during the battle with the random villain, Dennis suddenly develops vampire powers!
Now Mavis can stay, because it turns out he is a vampire. Hooray!
  While the Accept one anothers differences is a good message, it doesnt work because Dennis isn't different.
  The real theme seems to be: Those who seem different will soon reveal that they're not. Just be patient! Real inspiring, isn't it?

Theres also the annoying idea that Women can do anything better than men. This is a specially true in Mavis. Shes more a better parent than her husband. Shes a better biker than he is, and so on.

One last thing. The acting sounds very half-hearted, almost if the actors wanted to be somewhere else. Even Steve Buscemi, who plays Wayne the Werewolf. He sounded much better as Randall in the Monsters Inc movies.

7. Would I recommend this film?
No. There are worse films than Hotel Transylvania 2, but there are also much better films.

Back in 2012 when Sony, under Genndy Tartakovskys direction, released the star-studded monster comedy Hotel Transylvania upon the world, it seemed like a simple formula for success.  In fact thats exactly what it turned out to be, turning its 85-million dollar budget into $358.4-million at the box office alone.  Most importantly, perhaps, is that those kind of profits assure beyond any shadow of a doubt that sequels will follow.

And follow they have- in September of 2015 Hotel Transylvania 2 was released once again under Tartakovskys directorial efforts only this time leading voice actor Adam Sandler co-wrote the script to insure maximum laughs.  The budget was $80-mil (rare that a sequel to so successful a debut would have a smaller budget) and the film managed to collect a cool $473-million at the box office this time.  Less money to produce and even larger profits mean you can bet your high-collared cape this isn't the last well be hearing from Hotel Trans.

The story in Hotel Transylvania 2 doesnt bother treading old territory but rather picks up with events just as we left them at the conclusion of the first movie:  Dracs (Sandler) daughter Mavis (Selena Gomez) ties the knot with dopey human suitor Jonathan (Andy Samberg) and a wedding at the hotel means human guests amongst monsters.  -You may remember from the first film that even a single human was a terrifying prospect for the monsters.

From the gags of such intermingling, the viewer is quickly whisked along lifes highway as the couple announce they're pregnancy, have a baby boy, and discover a bit of trouble when the lad (Dennis) doesnt seem to be following in the familys vampiric traditions.  Could he be just a late fanger? Could Drac (and his even nastier father Vlad voiced by Mel Brooks) love their grandson if he was more human than monster?  Will Mavis just give up on the whole hotel altogether and move to California with her in-laws so that Dennis can hope to grow up normally among humans?

These are just some of the sleep-depriving questions Hotel Transylvania 2 presents and if it all sounds a bit contrived, thats because it is.  Depth of plot or awards for best drama aren't the name of the game here but that doesnt mean there aren't a few laughs to be had with Steve Buscemi reprising his role as the Wolfman, Kevin James as Frankenstein, David Spade as the Invisible Man and even John Lovits as the Phantom of the Opera.  The jokes are new but the gags largely unchanged.

About the biggest problem I found with the piece is that its pacing is far from even.  In one sense its doing its best to offer up some heavy handed themes of individualism, political correctness, unconditional parental love and so on but then in another it sorts of dares its viewer to stop worrying about lessons and just laugh at the silliness.  This isn't an inexcusable crime by itself (after all, the kids will likely be enamored with the slapstick anyway), the bigger problem here is that the film attempts so much in its 89-minutes that certain things drag on unnecessarily while other touchstone moments (like marriage and childbirth) are glanced over at blink-and-you-missed-it speeds.  I suppose another way of saying it: the pacing in the first film is vastly more organized than how things come together in the second.

On the other hand, if you were the type of viewer who enjoyed the shtick of Drac being a bit overprotective (over-imposing?) of daughter Mavis in the first film, get ready for overload status in the second.  Thankfully for most of the movie Drac and Mavis aren't in the same locale, which provides many more opportunities for effects-laden monster mischief; the fire effects are particular have gotten to the point of photo-realism here.

All in all, Hotel Transylvania 2 is an enjoyable romp despite being slightly unsure of precisely how serious to take itself.  Fans of the original will likely find much to enjoy here.  The gags are pretty continuous and a few of them are funny enough to atone for some of the cornier ones.  By no means the film reinvent the CG medium but it builds upon many of the same elements that made the first film memorable.

Oh and that was no mere conjecture in my stating the sequels are a coming.  Part 3 is already in the works for a 2018 release and an animated television series is set to drop in early 2017.  Sonys been around long enough to know there is no sense fixing that which isn't broken.

Oddly enough, it was a trailer for "Hotel Transylvania 2" that led me to check out the original "Hotel Transylvania."  While the second movie looked like it would be cute and funny, I wanted to learn the backstory behind it first -- generally watching the sequel before the original movie is just a recipe for confusion.  And I thought the first movie was adorable and fun, and hoped the second would be just as enjoyable.  And while it does have a few problems (more on that later), it's still a great ride, both funny and heartwarming and with the always-timely message of accepting others despite their appearances.

After the events of "Hotel Transylvania," laid-back slacker Johnny has married Mavis, the adorable daughter of Count Dracula himself, and the two of them now have a son, Dennis.  Dracula couldn't be happier to be a grandfather... except for the fact that Dennis has shown no signs of becoming a vampire.  When Johnny and Mavis plan to move away from the Hotel Transylvania so Dennis can be around normal humans, Drac panics, and he and his monster friends decide to take his grandson on a road trip to show him the joys of being a monster and to hopefully kick-start his inner vampire before his fifth birthday rolls around.  But Mavis isn't happy with her father's antics... and Vlad, Drac's traditionalist father, isn't happy with the idea of having humans in the family...

Like the first film, this film has colorful, stylized animation that keeps up a quick pace without ever feeling rushed or frantic.  It looks fantastic, though with a heavyweight like Genndy Tartakovsky (the man behind "Samurai Jack" and the 2D "Clone Wars" cartoons) at the helm, it's no wonder the film came out looking so great.  Traditional monsters are still recognizable but also maintain their own unique looks, and the human characters are stylized enough to avoid the uncanny valley without also looking grotesque or weird.

Most of the original voice cast has returned for this film, with the exception of CeeLo Green (Murray the mummy is now voiced by Keegan-Michael Key of "Key and Peele," though I didn't notice a significant difference between the voices).  Even Jon Lovitz makes a reappearance despite Quasimodo vanishing between films (he's now the Phantom of the Opera), and Mel Brooks makes a hilarious cameo as Vlad, bringing his trademark snarky, crotchety-old-man humor to the film.

While the film is mostly just as fun and heartwarming as the original, this film, much like its predecessor, feels the need to throw in a villain for no apparent reason.  Not every film needs an antagonist, and this film's bad guy, a giant bat named Bela, feels out of place and forced in simply for the sake of having a human-hating villain.  We didn't necessarily need a villain or a climactic action scene to make this film work -- the first film worked just fine without a fight scene at the end (though it, too, had a villain tossed in simply for the sake of having a villain).

That beef aside, this film is still a sweet and funny ride through a world where humans and monsters live side by side, and an enjoyable romp with characters we've come to know and love.  Probably best for ages 8 and up due to some scary scenes and bathroom humor.

Now that Dracula (Adam Sandler) has opened the Hotel Transylvania's doors to humans, things are changing for the better; however, Drac is secretly worried that his half-human grandson, Dennis, isn't showing his vampire side. But things really get batty when Drac's cantankerous, old-school dad (Mel Brooks) pays an unexpected visit.

No spoilers, I promise! The second visit to Hotel Transylvania is fun & in the same spirit as the first. Convinced the child can only be vampire based on years and years of vampire bloodlines "vampa" (vampire grandpa) starts spending SO MUCH TIME worrying about whether or not little Dennis will become a vampire that he ends up pushing his daughter away. About halfway through the movie my brother in law snuck in and ended up watching the movie with us. Everyone chuckled and giggled and laughed because this movie was HILARIOUS! After a brusque beginning, which rushes through the marriage, the pregnancy, the baby............and then suddenly the baby is five!!!  (Its like flipping through a photo album and not taking the time to actually look at the pictures)!  After this begrudging prologue, the story is reduced to a simple plot device: worrying about whether the kid is a vampire or not.  Grandpa (Adam Sandler) is adamant, his grandson is a vampire; his fangs just haven't grown in yet, so he tries to scare the kid into turning.  Thats it.  They spend the entire movie racing through gags all focused on making/proving the kid is a vampire.  Apparently, hes not good enough the way he is (which is a disconcerting message).  If he expects to fit in with this crowd, hes got to be a monster.  And the right sort of monster.

Im not a fan of Adam Sandler but not having him on screen is a great asset.  I was amused more often than not.  I laughed at most of the jokes.  Its a keeper.  But Im not going to brag about that.

I hate being negative, but I'm tired of Hollywood phoning in some of their work.  As personal opinions go, it felt as if the creators were pandering to the audience by expanding on some of the jokes and sight gags that made the first movie so endearing. "Hey, you liked this funny bit...Well, let's do it again, only this time not as well and we'll cram it in the script somehow!"  Like the original, the same hilarious, hyper-exaggerated cartoon animation was very well done, but it wasn't enough to fully rescue this sequel from its very lackluster writing. All in all, I would say it wasn't a terrible movie (I have seen worse), but one viewing was quite enough for me and my usually easy to please kids.  Glad we rented instead of bought.  So Mr. Negative here will conclude on a positive note:  Kudos for casting the legendary Mel Brooks as the curmundgeonly grandfather.  For now, I will continue to wait for the thoroughly likable Adam Sandler and Kevin James to do another good movie.

As far as I am concerned, Sandler has had three credible hits in his repertoire; The Water Boy, The Wedding Singer, and Hotel Transylvania.  So, I was naturally hyped for this much-anticipated sequel, hopeful that it would complement the originality of its predecessor, but worried that it would fall flat like most of Adam's recent jokes.  I am pleased to inform that the sequel is not only thoroughly entertaining and endearing but it effectively recaptures all of the charm, humor, and emotion of the first.  The full cast is back as big and vibrant as ever, with a few newcomers that energize all of the already over the top performances.  I mean, its pretty hard to lose when any comedy adds Mel Brooks, animated or not.  The story is simple but fun and engaging and its fast pace will keep both young and old riveted while taking just enough time for those heartfelt moments to have an impact without becoming overtly sappy.  Genndy Tartakovsky should direct all of Mr. Sandler's films; he might find a renewed success as opposed to his latest run of nonsensical excess and box office poverty.

When the original "Hotel Transylvania" was released, I'm afraid to say I never caught it in the theater. I instead waited until it came to DVD to check it out, and immediately regretted not seeing it on the big screen, for I loved the simple, but funny plotline, and all the loveable and relatable characters. So much so, that the movie is now a staple for my folks and I to watch every Halloween. (And it helps that Genndy Tartakofski of "Dexter's Lab" and "Samurai Jack" fame directed it and had a hand in the writing.) So when a sequel was announced, you can bet we were all hyped to see it.

The verdict? While the first movie is far superior, this new adventure with the hotel monster crew is still fairly enjoyable, and kept us laughing all the way through.

Taking place seven years after the first film, Dracula has since opened up his hotel to also include human guests, resulting in the general public now being fairly used to mingling with monsters. Mavis and Johnny are happily married, and soon give birth to their half human/half vampire son, Dennis. But as the years tick by with Dennis showing no signs of developing any vampire abilities, Dracula begins to worry, especially when his daughter considers moving away with Johnny to raise their son among normal humans. When the couple goes to visit Johnny's parents, Dracula (with the help of his friends) hatches a plan to help force Dennis' powers to emerge, and teach him how to be a "proper" monster (as well as to ensure that Mavis and Johnny stay at the hotel). But when Dracula's human-hating father shows up and discovers his great-grandson's duel heritage, Dracula must come to terms with who and what his grandson is, and learn to let him be himself.

Starting with the good, all of the characters that made the first movie great are back in full form, and are just as charming and funny as ever. (There's a monster-themed joke practically every five minutes--all of them hilarious.) With the hotel now open to humans, Johnny acts as a liaison between the monsters and humans;  helping Dracula get updated on modern technology, and introducing Mavis to his family and old hometown, all with gut-bustingly funny results. The new characters, such as Johnny's parents, are likeable, and Dennis is beyond adorable--wanting anything to just please both sides of his family. This leads to a rather important message about letting your kids just be who they are, especially when it comes to ones who come from families that are a mix of different races, cultures, or other heritages. Being that Dennis is half human/half vampire, both sides of his relatives just want what's best for him, but can't quite decide just what IS the right thing to do for him, especially when it's unclear if he'll ever develop vampire powers or not.

While this is all well and good, the plot, however, is a bit more disjointed, in comparison to the first movie. The previous film had a simple, solid plot that carried all the way through, about Dracula learning to accept humans, and let his sheltered daughter explore the world. The sequel, on the other hand, seems like it doesn't quite know what it wants to do at times. It seems that at this point, humans have accepted monsters as a part of their everyday life, which, while charming, pretty much negates any sort of dramatic tension the first movie had. The closest we get to any human/monster conflict comes in the form of Dracula's old fashioned father, Vlad...and while trailers and descriptions might make you think he plays a huge part in the plot, he actually doesn't show up until the last third of the movie (making the film's ending/big finale, while touching, admittedly VERY rushed). I feel his character would've served a much better purpose if he were introduced much earlier, and had a more active role in the plot, instead of just following the antics of Dracula and his buddies. It's as if the writers just came up with a bunch of funny monster jokes, and strung them all together, and then suddenly remembered "oh yeah, we need some conflict", and then hastily assembled an ending that pretty much takes us through the same story arc of the first movie, except in under ten minutes.  (Not to mention that at one point, Mavis casually tells her in-laws how her mother was killed by angry humans...to have such a driving force of the first movie be turned into a mere throwaway line is just....sad. )

While the movie isn't without its problems, I still none the less enjoyed it. The slick and expressive animation and great characters more than makes up for whatever I found lacking in the plot. It's a nice continuation of the gang's adventures, but doesn't really bring much new to the table either. The first film is far better, but if you liked the first movie, you'll most likely enjoy this new outing as well.
